etymologies: late 18th century; earliest use found in Daines Barrington (1727/8–1800), judge, antiquary, and naturalist. From Irish giolla rua (formerly giolla ruadh) from giolla young man, retainer, servant + rua, apparently so called on account of its reddish skin

definitions: A distinctive form of the brown trout (Salmo trutta) found in certain lakes in Ireland and (perhaps) Scotland, having a thickened stomach adapted to a diet rich in snails. More fully "gillaroo trout".

notes.text: The gillaroo of Lough Melvin, County Fermanagh, has been shown to be genetically distinct from other brown trout, and is now often classified as a separate species, Salmo stomachicus.
